concept: MCU-mediated mitochondrial calcium influx may establish local ATP gradients at presynaptic terminals that directly modulate synaptic vesicle release probability. This creates a novel mechanism linking subcellular energetic state to neural circuit timing precision through metabolic control of vesicle fusion kinetics.

rationale.statement: High-frequency neuronal firing triggers calcium influx through voltage-gated channels, which the mitochondrial calcium uniporter (MCU) complex captures to stimulate calcium-dependent dehydrogenases in the tricarboxylic acid cycle. This process enhances oxidative phosphorylation and ATP production during periods of elevated neuronal activity, establishing the foundational mechanism for activity-dependent metabolic coupling.

Super-resolution imaging reveals nanoscale co-localization of mitochondria with presynaptic active zones, enabling spatially specific ATP microdomains to form at release sites. These localized gradients persist despite endogenous calcium buffering mechanisms and provide a distinct metabolic contribution compared to glycolytic ATP supply.

Presynaptic ATP availability directly controls the energetics of vesicle priming, fusion, and recycling machinery, with mitochondrial sources providing critical buffering during high-demand transmission. Experimental inhibition of oxidative phosphorylation selectively impairs synaptic recovery after depletion, demonstrating the causal necessity of MCU-mediated ATP production for sustaining vesicle release kinetics.

The temporal coupling between mitochondrial calcium dynamics and vesicle fusion kinetics enables metabolic regulation of synaptic timing precision. This mechanism allows subcellular energetic state to control neural information processing fidelity through millisecond-scale ATP adjustments that optimize neurotransmitter release during high-frequency activity.

The evolutionary conservation of MCU regulatory subunits across vertebrates with high-acuity sensory systems suggests a fundamental role for this mechanism in supporting demanding neural circuits. This metabolic control framework offers novel perspectives on how energetic states modulate neural computation and circuit-level phenomena including synchrony and plasticity.
